Well, first, you should have taken the Sub-S Election with your current LLC for the Web Development. The Sub-S Election is for Federal Taxes only and allows you to minimize your tax burden significantly. Most small businesses are eligible, but you may want to double check. If you don't elect to be an S-LLC your going to have to pay Self Employment Taxes.
Now, your Accountant was correct *IF* they were talking about the Airbnb rentals. The article you read was kind of misleading, because regardless of how long they stay, so long as you make $0.01 (yes, a penny) the IRS wants you to claim that as "gross income." Airbnb may only send you a tax form if they stay longer than 14 days or whatnot, that's something you have to read in their "Terms and Services" when you use them as a broker.
I'm not a tax expert, and I'm not going to represent that I am. I suggest that you should go a schedule a free consultation with one to lay everything on the table so you can minimize your tax burden over everything you have going on.

You should *NOT* form an LLC for your random Airbnb stays. Your going to go through the hassle of paying the fees with your state, opening up a bank account, getting everything else in line...for what benefits?
Oh that's right, there is none in this scenario; you didn't even take a Sub-S election on your other LLC.
You should set up an business when you want to separate your business liability from your personal liability.
*You are not going to incur any liabilities, unless you turn your home into a bed and breakfast and you fail to pay your outstanding order for the complementary nightly Rocky Road ice cream bowl.*
Your homeowners insurance is or will usually cover guests, which these individuals are your guests...they just happen to be paying you.
Plus, your more than likely:
* (a) Not going to receive a tax form from Airbnb; and * (b) Not going to be audited by the IRS.
Everyone is so "LLC Crazy" now days, and they forget the fundamental purpose of such entity.
You have to update the blog and it must be original content. If you use someone's canned content Google's algorithm views that as a negative and effects you negatively in SEO sense.
Go ask the members of r/lawfirm they may be able to give you some better advice.

I would have done a few things:
* Taken the LSAT over to get a higher score * Attempt to get some type of scholarship * Lived with my parents * Try to minimize life expenses/ lifestyle change * Made payments before to minimize capitalization * Work more through law school to save/pay down the loan
...just to name a few...
I made the choices I did thinking I had to, brain washed almost by how I was raised, but in reality I didn't. Law school opened my eyes to a lot about life, and I'm thankful; I wouldn't trade the experience for anything. This is my reality, my life, and I'm thankful to be in the position I am; even if it means sacrificing for a little while longer.

* $155,000 * $197,000 w/ capitalized interest * $188,000 currently (just made $8,700 payment)
Shit is expensive if you go it alone. Looking back I would have made a few different choices, but I learned from what I borrowed; it is what it is. I have a good job and I'm aggressively paying it down. It's not going anywhere and the interest will kill me, so I've *embraced the suck and I'm going HAM!*

I'm in the legal field, language is very important to my life. I suppose I could have been more clear when differentiating the two portions of the student loan.
I'm not completely sold on the HELOC itself, for a few reasons:
* Usually they have a higher interest rate. I figured if I could refi the house while utilizing the HELOC cash to pay off my loans it would save us money over time in the form of less interest paid; * HELOC usually have Call Provisions in them, Google them, they suck; and * The loan right now on the house is not in my name so we would be adding me to the mortgage, maybe. I don't know the effect that will have on the overall math.
I looking for the ideal position for my family.

Your correct.
I'm securing and attaching my home to the amount I will be paying off, essentially rolling it over into the equity I've established. If I die, this amount will *not* be extinguished and my wife *will* be responsible for the reaming balance of our mortgage; hence the life insurance inquiry.
The remaining student loan account will have roughly $100,000 and has interest rates ranging from 4.9% to 5.6%, respectfully. If I die, this amount *will be* extinguished and my wife *will not* be responsible for the outstanding balance.
Perfect! Yea, CH 13 is pain and the plans suck; that was a smart move on your part. Keep up the good work, bud!

No offense, but it sounds like you have a little self-worth issue. Reality is you owe this money, and it will continue to grow by paying nothing towards it.
You have to proactively pay on this loan until its gone. Maybe the first step is changing your attitude here. We are all, probably, in some similar situation; I myself have $184,000 of student loan debt. I'm working 60 hours a week to pay it off as much as I can. I wanted to take advantage of the PSLF program, but I don't trust it will be around in 10 years, so I'm doing it on my own.
What's your budget like? What are your job hours life, could you get another job? Do you have the opportunity to get a higher paying job?
What type of car? Year, make, model, condition...essentially, what is the KBB value?

Clearly they are not a priority to you now. You should change your mindset on the loans IMO; $60,000 can easily pile up fast and like you said your not paying on them at all. If you sacrifice for 3-5 years you can easily pay off $60,000 of debt. What is your income now? What type of working field?

In your closing documents you should have a break down of who was paid what. Once, you get the original agreement I'd error on the side of caution, you may want to go speak with an Attorney. Communicate with the realtor in writing only and keep track of all correspondences.
Can I ask you why you *didn't* file bankruptcy? It looks like to me all of this debt was eligible for discharge.

It's in my nature to disagree with this comment. If the Statute of Limitations has rung, it's a moot point, they sat on their right.
Realistically, you need to read the contract you signed with them and determine if they were paid by the closing costs. You could have paid the fees, but somehow they were shafted on their share of the commission.

Read what you just wrote.
HELOC...It's just more cash you can use as you want to.
I want to use the HELOC to pay off my student loan account. You don't have to re-invest the HELOC money into your house. I know a HELOC isn't associated with my student loans, nothing is, hence my hesitation on attaching them to anything I hold jointly with my spouse.
Student loans don't have security associated with them; they don't need to, because they have other ways to get the money from you.
Again, the exact reason why I'm hesitant on attaching them. As of now, if I die, the loans are extinguished because they are Federally backed loans. If I attach them to ANYTHING, the lender will be able to seek repayment...even after my death. I'm not stupid. Thus, the primary reason I will only attach my debt to my house if I get life insurance which will allow my surviving spouse to pay off the secured debt upon my death.

From what I have read and discussed in length with multiple lenders, no.
When I was tire-kicking a few lenders they offered me an opportunity to finance the loans, but required me to pledge my house as collateral.

Oh, but you can. I've been offered this refi/HELOC hybrid by two different lenders.
I wasn't paying on the student loans because:
* I wasn't married and the home loan was not mine (still isn't technically); * My wife was working at the home loan before we were married...now we are refocusing our efforts on my student loans; and * I was wasn't paying on the student loans because I had to live and could only work part time.

WRITING.TITLE: Roll Student Debt/Mortgage Refi Question
WRITING.TEXT:
As the title suggests, I'd like to roll some of my student loan debt into my residence by utilizing some of the equity I've established.
* Property FMV: $180,000.00 * Mortgage Balance: $87,000.00 * Mortgage Type: 30 YR Fixed Rate * Interest Rate: 4.25%
I have two accounts with X Student Loan Service for a total student debt amount of $184,000.00 currently. I just processed a principal payment of $8,700 towards knocking out the highest interest loan disbursement which was at 7.65%. I'm sure I will get a lot of comments about why it's so high and asking what I do; I've attended law school and I'm in the licensing process to become an Attorney. That being said, my one accounts of "Direct Grad Plus" loans has $84,000.00 of debt and is ranging from 7.65% to 6.59% with interest rates.
My main reason why I was hesitant on attaching the student debt to the property was the fact that it wouldn't terminate upon my death. I will only attach it to the property if I can get life insurance to cover the payoff amount to safe guard my wife. We currently have around $22,000.00 in our savings account as an emergency fund. I'm a contracted consultant for a law firm on a very prominent case which can, but most likely won't, be discontinued at any time and my wife works two jobs both of which are very secure. We have a very minimal lifestyle, we only have the usual household utilities and our mortgage to pay on monthly; we've paid off our cars.
We live in a rural mid-western portion of the USA if that matters. We purchased our home in 2014 for $145,000 and put $30,000 down when we purchased; the surrounding area has appreciated significantly. I don't want to make a poor decision with regard to the two biggest investments I've made in my life so far, any help is greatly appreciated.
My questions are simple:
* Has anyone done this? * Where would I go for life insurance? What should I consider? (28 years old; non-smoker; very light drinker) * What would be a good rate for life insurance? * Should I consider doing 15 yr vs. 30 yr? * Rates are rising, what should I consider a favorable refi rate? * Is there anyway I can get away from closing costs? * (Insert question I can't think of right now...)
Why do you want to go to law school? One class should not be the basis of such a monumental decision.

Yes, I consider myself healthy. I would like to play basketball more often, but I'm always on the go and I eat relatively healthy. I don't drink soda or munch on snacks. I have the occasional beer, but don't over indulged; most people don't live the lifestyle I do though. You have to be smart about what you put in, and since you have not attended law school, you haven't learned that most people don't know how to keep a healthy balance.

So, your not in law school?
I'd argue that before law school I couldn't work more than 45-50 hours per week.
Law school easily conditioned me to put in 50+ hours of "work," but you have to remember this is significantly different work than your thinking. The work you will be doing is purely mental and over the three years your brain is conditioned to put out for prolonged periods at a higher than normal intellectual level.
This is the same with my firm. I only have to bill 40, but I'm a hustler by nature, and agree with your comment about earning your keep.
I'm making money, that's all I care about; I just threw down $8,700 on my student loans.

I work 60 hours a week currently. I can peak out at 75 before I start to feel like a zombie; I'm sure I could easily push more, though.
Edit: Only reason why I'm at the firm I am is because I outlasted and out performed 5 other individuals. So, as long as they don't have a problem paying me for 60hrs a week, I'm going to continue to put in the time. You get what you put in!

It's the best thing to do in your circumstances.
It's very normal for LLCs to be set up this way so it shouldn't be anything that will cost you more money. In my state, it's literally a "check the box" to select manager-managed entity and explicitly laying out the managers powers in the operating agreement.
This is so specific...is this a problem for class? If so, don't get caught it will go down *on your permanent record.*
Your going to get addicted...welcome, welcome to the club.
His math in the beginning of his video IS NOT CORRECT! I cringe every time I hear him talk.

Yes, it's a promise to repay the lender. It's a contract for repayment; contracts are just promises to do something in exchange for consideration.
You signed a "master promissory note" when you took your loans out.
It is paramount you, yourself, get an Attorney involved to protect your interests. You don't want any balloon payments and you want the 0% interest explicit; all this needs to be in the contract.
I bought an S-Video one and it works AWESOME!

Your attorney friend doesn't practice business law.
You can set the LLC up 50/50 revenue wise, that's fine. You should look into a manager-managed system of control.
That way you elect someone to make the business decisions, which takes out the possibility of voting into a deadlock.
Your going to want a very precise operating agreement written out that explicitly outlines who has what power, etc. I would suggest NOT going with a DIY boilerplate legal document from legalzoom; if you do problems WILL arise in the future. Plus in most states, LLCs are set up by default as member-managed entities; manager-managed is an election, much like your Sub-S election you SHOULD look into as well.

You neeeeeeeeeed to have a lawyer draft a promissory note. I'd suggest seeking a free consultation from a local contract/business attorney.
I can't stress this enough.
I HATE his advertisements!

Federal Student loans give you a lot of options for repayment. If you REFI you loans with a private lender your going to paint yourself into a narrow corner of repayment. I would suggest against it until you graduate, are out of the deferment period, and have payed down the loans for a while. IT is a growing field and you will get a good job somewhere when your done, so don't stress now.

So annoying. I had the same thing happen to me with a VERY RARE book I bought for $45.00 at auction; the book is easily worth $200+ in any condition, and this book was flawless.
The Seller told me she was not going to sell it to me because there was conditional issues she did not disclose in the auction description. I told her I didn't care and would take it regardless if it was in a tub of water. She wouldn't budge and was an asshole about the whole thing, so I Neg'd her. I didn't want to, but that is just wrong.
I wanted to file a suit in small claims court to force her to sell the book to me, but she lived in Texas and it would have cost me more than the books worth to do so. Had I known someone in Texas...I'd have that book.

I had an internship with a law firm that specialized in construction law, and like another comment said here, it is *VERY* broad topic.
I did a lot of Condo Construction and general land splitting for personal development. With the splitting we drafted a lot of documents associated with transferring of ownership and easements. With the Condo Construction, we drafted a lot of the Master Deeds in accordance with our state's [Condominium Act](http://www.legislature.mi.gov/documents/mcl/pdf/mcl-act-59-of-1978.pdf)...your state may have similar legislation.
Since your in CA, I'd be knowledgeable about commercial leaseholds. We had a few clients that were developers, but whom also had commercial property we did the lease work on and had to evict a few tenants.
You should really know contract and property law rather well. I love this shit, if you come to a cross-road feel free to PM me and I will do my best to help you in your quest.

I'd second this. You can easily jump right in and search with the lexis/west engines, but your going to have a narrow view of your issue.
I would suggest Google first to see if there are any connecting issues that tug at your overall issue. Then once you have a good understanding, go into Lexis/West and use the Secondary sources to get a great overview of the law associated with your issue. Once you have that done, you will know what your NOT looking for, and in turn you're going to be a lot better off.
It's a stylistic thing, your going to search the way your comfortable.

The Christmas ornaments are pretty hard to move actually. The Christmas train depends on what number, I'd say the first 15 cars are pretty common. It's when you get into the later train cars that will run upwards of $85-$100+; people just got sick of paying $25 with shipping. If you do the math there were 40 cars at $25 each, that's $1000 total! The Halloween train is a little bit more hard to find and does fetch around $35-$40 per car, but same thing with the Christmas Train, later cars are worth much much more. The Christmas Village and Halloween Villages will fetch you quite a haul as well; same concept as with the trains, the later pieces are worth more. The Halloween Village is especially hard to come by and is highly sought by collectors. I was fortunate as to how bad this collector wanted everything; she paid full price and shipping.

Random bricks can be fun to buy if you can find them cheap enough. I mostly look for retired sets I can easily flip. Sometimes I will take a stab at open sets, complete them to know what is missing/there, and then either buy the missing bricks/grab one I have or just sell it incomplete depending on the set; really depends on what I find and for what price. The booklets and boxes are super important to have, condition is everything. I'm not a huge mini figure guy, unless it's the super rare ones.

It was their Hamilton figures. It was a few complete sets and a lot of the rare figures. Since she was in was in Australia and wanted every item I had, I sold them all at a premium price; she didn't mind because she couldn't get them otherwise.
They look like cats trying to climb out of a tub filled with water.

It's harder to do both portions on eBay. It really takes an ignorant Seller to find an item significantly lower and worth your time, but it can be done. If a Seller takes 5min to research before listing they can prevent listing at a low price; some people just don't care though.

I have quite a lot I watch. Old books, Legos, vintage fishing lures, The Simpsons stuff, Old tin type photos, video games...I do a lot of antique things...a lot of smalls because they are easier to ship. What ever I can make a buck on. I'm constantly looking up stuff I find.

You are right! I found one in the trash and looked it up on eBay real quick and saw one comparable sell at $150...instantly snatched it up and found five more rummaging through the rest of the trash.
They were store over sized displays of their men's and women's perfumes, epically rare from what the gentlemen I sold them to said; he had a perfume business himself.

If free trash counts...I obtained some Louis Vuitton Store perfume displays and sold them to a gentleman in Chicago for $750 each; I had 6 for a total of $4,500 profit.
If your counting item(s) I purchased: I bought some sets of The Simpsons Figures off craigslist and sold them all to one individual in Australia for $3,550 for a $3,250 profit.

I did this two weeks ago. The Seller had a Buy-it-Now for $75.00 and I offered $50.00...they accepted. When I received the item I sold it three days later for $135.00 on the same site. I do this quite often for the category of goods I watch;it's call arbitrage.
My comment was slightly sarcastic in nature. Your right though. I don't know how the law school can justify it, maybe it's just aimed at obtaining publicity for sticking up for the little guy.

I have an issue with the MBE statistics. In my state, MI, they removed the ability to test out of the state writing portion. Additionally, Civil Procedure was added to the mix as well. They expect us to know more law, but then complain about the drop in scores? If I could have tested out of the writing portion I would have dedicated all my time on the 8 subjects, instead of the 20+ subjects if you count state distinctions and MBE topics.

At least! It is really going to depend on the quality of studying your going to do. Quality is paramount to quantity; your going to want to know this stuff and it just spill out when you talk.

I treated it like a full-time gig. I graduated in middle of May 16' and started slowly studying the Themis work. I ramped up my studying June 1 and did Monday-Friday,sometimes weekends, up until I took the exam in July. I did mostly 6/7:00am-5:00pm and would work past that most days when my wife worked late. Biggest thing is routine; establish one and maintain it.
Edit: Not to be a dick, but you get what you put in.

I would strongly suggest against this; unless, you want to be a science project for all of us.
I quit my job to study. I was a middle of the pack A-/B+/B student in law school. It's not worth risking it. Your going to need a lot more than two weeks to focus on everything, practice, and hone your skills. I did 8-9 hours a day with Themis and passed by a fair margin on my first time last July.

After reading this article I went and looked at the small amount of paper money I have in my house. I was pleased to find a 1977 US $100 note with serial number: A0005535*...should be worth a little more than $100 on eBay. Thanks!
